Throughout my work in the SWANA region and beyond, I have developed a strong ability to adapt materials and training approaches to different cultural contexts. This has been particularly important in my work with Bloom, where I have designed and delivered curricula for social entrepreneurs across a wide range of countries and communities.
One of the key principles that guides my approach to cultural adaptation is a commitment to centering the needs and perspectives of learners themselves. Rather than imposing a one-size-fits-all curriculum or set of practices, I work closely with learners to understand their unique contexts, challenges, and goals, and to co-create learning experiences that are relevant and meaningful to them.
This often involves a significant degree of flexibility and adaptation on my part as a facilitator and curriculum designer. For example, in my work with social entrepreneurs in Lebanon, I have had to navigate complex political and social dynamics, adapting my language, examples, and activities to ensure that they are sensitive to local realities and concerns.
At the same time, I have also worked to build a culture of openness, dialogue, and mutual learning in my engagements with learners from different cultural contexts. By creating spaces for honest conversation and exchange, I have been able to foster a sense of trust and collaboration that allows for genuine learning and growth on all sides.
Ultimately, my ability to adapt materials and training approaches to different cultural contexts is grounded in a deep respect for the diversity of human experiences and a commitment to meeting learners where they are. By working collaboratively with learners to design and deliver curricula that are culturally relevant and responsive, I have been able to drive meaningful impact and change in a wide range of contexts. This experience has equipped me with the skills and mindset needed to navigate complex cultural dynamics in service of the UN's objectives.
Cultural Sensitivity in Training

How can we change materials and training to fit different cultures? First, we need to speak the language and let the learners lead. This helps us be careful with their culture. We don't tell them what to do. We answer their questions. We listen before we give advice.

The main idea is that the learner should feel in control. They need to believe they can do things on their own. This will help us be more careful with their culture because we will talk less and learn more.

We shouldn't just try to be careful around other cultures. We should learn from each other. We want to help people find jobs and learn new skills after hard times. To do this, we need to ask questions and listen.

Our training guides show how we put learners in control. We ask them questions and help them think for themselves. This way, we can understand different cultures better and help people learn more.
A good question helps them find answers. However, mentors should help students to think deeply about different cultures. They should guide them to learn and see that they know the answers.

use this one, and focus on the openness and letting the learner lead, socratic method, as well as include the story about nawres who told me that iraqi's need a clean space with leadership and that a consensus based organization wouldn't work and i refused at first, and then i realied he knew his people best and that now science camp is still alive and active so many years later probably because i let go of the idea that i knew best

So, how do I adapt materials and training approaches to different cultural contexts? Well, first and foremost, we speak the language and we have the program fundamentally be driven by the entrepreneurs. I think this is the most important thing for creating cultural sensitivity. We are not bringing in external trainers to tell them what to do. We are bringing in external trainers to answer their questions. We don't offer our advice until we ask them for their advice. And this is a foundational element in my pedagogical framing and understanding, is that the learner is in the driver's seat. The concept is entrepreneurial self-efficacy. And without entrepreneurial self-efficacy, there is very little that is valuable in an entrepreneur following the guide coming from external places. And this is going to be able to support us in making it culturally sensitive because We will talk less, first of all. That's just the simplest structural difference, but also it is where we will start to learn. It's not about being culturally sensitive. That implies even that we know better and that we are big and that we can accidentally damage something small. And rather than think of things as sensitivity, I think we need to think about it in the framing of exchange, that we are here just as much as they are here to learn. Because the question that we're trying to ask about how do we connect sustainability with creating jobs and learning and skills development for people in a place that are emerging from devastation and violence and the infrastructural destruction is a big question. And I don't think that we need to come in to be sensitive necessarily. I think, yes, we need to speak in Arabic for sure. Yes, there is some element of learning some of the cultural nuances to be able to show that you are connecting and care. But fundamentally, the more deeper care comes from inverting it and asking them questions. And this is foundational in our approach. And to create the structural frameworks within our organization, I have included this in our training manuals for our trainers, which you can see here, and for our mentors. And rather than describe cultural sensitivity, I'm working on creating an approach that puts the learner in the driver's seat, reduces the amount of contribution coming from the mentors and the trainers, and increasing the amount of self-reflection and knowledge, and creating an induced sort of Socratic method where, for sure, if the mentor or trainer is asked a specific question, they can answer. But the more important thing for cultural sensitivity is for the mentors and trainers to be asking them to look within, to ask them to respond, and to ask them the next question that guides them to the next insight that lets them learn that they already knew the answer to their questions all along.

*Your response, emulating your writing style and incorporating the anecdote about Nawres:*

In adapting materials and training approaches to different cultural contexts, the key lies in embracing openness and letting the learners lead. This principle has been a cornerstone of my work, particularly in regions like Ninewa, where cultural nuances and local realities shape the effectiveness of any intervention.

I recall a pivotal moment when Nawres, an Iraqi entrepreneur, shared his insight that his community needed a clean space with clear leadership, rather than a consensus-based organization. Initially, I struggled with this feedback, believing that my approach was the best fit. However, upon reflection, I realized that Nawres knew his people best, and that my role was to listen, learn, and adapt.

This experience taught me the power of the Socratic method in cultural adaptation. By asking questions and empowering learners to find their own answers, we create a space for genuine understanding and locally-driven solutions. This approach has been instrumental in the longevity and impact of initiatives like Science Camp, which continues to thrive years later, likely because I let go of the notion that I knew best.

In my work, I strive to embed this philosophy into the very fabric of our training manuals and mentor guidelines. We prioritize reducing external contributions, increasing self-reflection, and guiding learners to uncover the wisdom they already possess. This not only fosters cultural sensitivity but also builds the entrepreneurial self-efficacy necessary for sustainable change.

Ultimately, adapting to different cultural contexts is not about being sensitive to avoid damage, but about engaging in a genuine exchange of learning. By speaking the language, asking questions, and letting the learners lead, we create the conditions for transformative impact that honors local needs and practices. This approach, honed through experiences like those with Nawres, equips me to effectively navigate the complex cultural landscape of regions like Ninewa, in service of the UN's objectives.
